Culture.question: How do teams collaborate with each other?
Culture.level2: Development teams collaborate on a limited scale, the same goes for Operations teams. There is no substantial collaboration between dev, ops and supporting teams
Culture.level3: Development teams collaborate on a reasonable and acceptable scale, the same goes for Operations teams. There is no substantial collaboration between dev, ops and supporting teams
Culture.level4: Development teams collaborate reasonably well, the same goes for Operations teams. There is no intensive collaboration between dev & ops teams, but supporting teams (arch, sec) and the business are involved significantly in dev teams
Culture.level5: Teams are multidisciplinary by default and contain all required competences and disciplines to deliver end-to-end value. Collaboration is principle-based and very effective.

Culture.question: To what extent is co-location integrated in the set-up of the teams?
Culture.level1: Teams are not co-located at all, no co-location policy
Culture.level2: Teams are located by their department/function, so separate locations/rooms for architects, developers, testers, ops, etc.
Culture.level3: Dev and Ops teams are mostly located in the same building
Culture.level4: Dev and Ops teams are located near each other, on the same floor or in the same room, supporting functions are located further away
Culture.level5: All relevant disciplines and roles in the value chain are co-located and very much near each other, mostly in the same room

Culture.question: Are individuals and teams focused on learning from each other?
Culture.level1: Learning is not an explicit aspect in the organization
Culture.level2: Some roles and responsibilities have been assigned to learning, but it is not considered part of daily work
Culture.level3: Individual lessons and learning results are present, but these are not shared within or between teams
Culture.level4: Learning is actively stimulated and executed on team level, and occasionally between teams
Culture.level5: All individuals are T-shaped (are familiar with multiple side-domains besides their core expertise), fails are considered valuable and learnings are actively rewarded. Learnings are shared across teams as well.

Culture.question: How are the organization levels (strategic to operational) aligned with each other?
Culture.level1: There is no visible alignment between the different organization levels
Culture.level2: Departments have their own objectives and decision making frameworks, steering is top-down
Culture.level3: Most steering and alignment is performed top-down, some interactions between the operational teams
Culture.level4: Bottom-up alignment is done via product (PO) and process (SM) roles. No visible links with portfolio & strategic decision making
Culture.level5: Portfolio (strategic, decision making), program (coordination) and teams (execution, value realization) are completely transparent to each other. Bottom-up and top-down are fully aligned.

Culture.question: Are individuals involved in defining team values?
Culture.level3: In some cases, for some teams
Culture.level4: For most teams we have individuals contributing to the team values
Culture.level5: Every team and every member is involved in defining cultural values

Culture.question: Are cultural values translated into behaviour?
Culture.level1: We do not have explicit cultural values
Culture.level2: We have cultural values, but no idea of the actual desired behaviour
Culture.level3: We have an implicit idea of the desired behaviour, but not explicitly defined
Culture.level4: Cultural values are translated by the teams in desired behaviour
Culture.level5: Cultural values are translated into desired behaviour for the teams, their stakeholders AND managers

Culture.question: How would you describe your organizational culture?
Culture.level1: Ad hoc, low on professional behaviour, little communication and alignment, low transparency
Culture.level2: Procedural, plans are leading, supporting processes are regarded as bureaucratic
Culture.level3: Flexible, able to cope with planned changes, difficulty with uncertainty and risks
Culture.level4: Self-organizing teams, high on trust and low on procedures
Culture.level5: Self-selecting teams, continuously learning/experimenting and safe-to-fail

Culture.question: To which level are teams able to make their own decisions?
Culture.level1: Decisions are not explicitly taken, communicated nor owned in the organization
Culture.level2: Decisions are taken on a central level, teams are not empowered
Culture.level3: Teams can make some decisions on their own, but are often constrained by management and silo behaviour
Culture.level4: Teams are able to make their own decisions, have clear ownership and involvement from the business, but still separate decision models for dev and ops
Culture.level5: Management provide a vision, but leave decision making to the teams, which share principles, practices and resources across bus, dev, ops and all supporting functions

Culture.question: To which extent are your teams focused on creating value for their customers?
Culture.level2: The teams are implicitly aware of the desired customer value, but not defined nor measured
Culture.level3: Customer value is clearly defined, but not measured
Culture.level4: Customer value is clearly defined, and measured on an ad hoc, manual basis
Culture.level5: Customer value is clearly defined and continuously measured with maximum automation and continuous feedback loops

Culture.question: To which extent do the team goals relate to the organizational goals?
Culture.level2: Team goals are not clearly related to corporate goals
Culture.level3: Team goals are partly in sync with the corporate goals, multiple differences between dev and ops goals
Culture.level4: Team goals are mostly in sync with the corporate goals, dev and ops have some separate and some shared goals, which are measured manually on an ad hoc basis
Culture.level5: Team goals are completely in sync with the corporate goals, dev and ops have shared goals which are mostly measured automatically

Culture.question: Who is responsible for the quality of the product(s)?
Culture.level4: The team is responsible for the quality, however responsibility is not for the whole lifecycle, but separated between dev and ops part
Culture.level5: The team as a whole, including everyone from bus, dev or ops, is responsible for the quality during the entire lifecycle of the product/service

Culture.question: Are teams focused on continuously improving themselves?
Culture.level2: Continuous improvement is performed on an ad hoc basis, and is managed  outside of the teams
Culture.level3: Continuous improvement is performed on a structural basis, mostly managed and executed outside of the teams
Culture.level4: Continuous improvement is embedded into the team processes and behaviours
Culture.level5: Continuous improvement is the most important objective of the teams, even more important than their daily work, which is demonstrated by real-time measurable value contribution of improvements

Culture.question: Does the organization facilitate development and growth for individuals and teams?
Culture.level1: Very seldom, and ad hoc at most
Culture.level2: There are some HR procedures and roles to support this, but in reality this is not an important topic
Culture.level3: Individuals are stimulated to develop themselves, this does not relate to team development or goals
Culture.level4: Individuals are stimulated to develop themselves, this is very much related to team development and goals. Training usually happens outside office hours.
Culture.level5: Whether you are from dev, ops, business or any other function, all desirable development and growth is supported by the organization, in money and time.

Culture.question: Is there room for experimentation within the teams?
Culture.level1: If we do experiments, they are done unintentionally and we do not learn from them
Culture.level2: Experiments are not embraced, it brings too much risk
Culture.level3: We do have some planned experiments, learnings are not explicitly registered or shared
Culture.level4: We have several experiments, learnings are shared within the team
Culture.level5: Experimenting is part of daily work.

Culture.question: Is the organization able to react fast when it comes to changes?
Culture.level1: Changes are only causing failures, therefore we try to limit them as much as possible
Culture.level2: Changes are usually implemented too late, mostly due to regulations, procedures and lack of collaboration, leading to long and non-competitive lead times
Culture.level3: Our organization is flexible, so we can deal with planned changes in a fast and iterative way, but have some trouble with lead times of unplanned work
Culture.level4: We work in an agile way, so we can respond to both planned and unplanned changes in an acceptable time frame, although the delivery chain is not fully automated and can lead to undesirable waiting time before production
Culture.level5: Our lead times to both failure recovery and changes are highly competitive and their underlying processes are (almost) fully automated

Automation.question: What is your code commit frequency?
Automation.level2: Once per month
Automation.level3: Once per week
Automation.level4: Once per day

Automation.question: When working on a new project how often do you commit your changes? After eachâ€¦
Automation.level2: project
Automation.level3: feature
Automation.level4: function

Automation.question: Which items are under version control?
Automation.level2: source code and config. files
Automation.level3: source code, config. files and generated code (by build and/or IDE)
Automation.level4: source code, config. files, generated code, third party libraries

Automation.question: How do you deal with branching?
Automation.level2: for each task on the sprint backlog a feature branch
Automation.level3: for each story on the sprint backlog a feature branch
Automation.level4: master and develop branch

Automation.question: How are your builds triggered?
Automation.level2: Manual
Automation.level3: Mostly manual
Automation.level4: Mostly automated

Automation.question: How often are builds made?
Automation.level2: Weekly
Automation.level3: Daily
Automation.level4: Hourly

Automation.question: How are your build artefacts managed?
Automation.level2: Manual
Automation.level3: Mostly manual
Automation.level4: Mostly automated, some manual interventions

Automation.question: To what extent are your tests automated?
What is the role of peer reviews in your delivery processes?
Automation.level2: Established as procedures, but not carried out consistently
Automation.level3: Some teams use peer reviews
Automation.level4: Pair programming is a common practice and measured

Automation.question: What is your common practice for test data management?
Automation.level2: Some procedures identified
Automation.level3: Some manual and some automated test data management processes, not production like
Automation.level4: Partly automated test data management, production like

Automation.question: To what extent are your deployments done manually?
Automation.level2: Completely manual, with structured procedures
Automation.level3: Mostly manual, some scripts
Automation.level4: Mostly automated, some manual interventions

Automation.question: How do you track and measure the quality of your deployments?
Automation.level2: Fully manual measurement, ad hoc
Automation.level3: Manual, but structural measurement
Automation.level4: Some automated tests

Automation.question: How long does it take for one line of code from the moment it is written until it is put into production?
Automation.level2: 5-10 days
Automation.level3: 2-5 days
Automation.level4: Hours

Automation.question: How do you provision new build and test environments?
Automation.level2: Manual procedures, takes a long time
Automation.level3: Mostly manual, delivery times often too long
Automation.level4: Mostly code-driven and automated, delivery times fairly acceptable

Automation.question: How do you provision new production environments?
Automation.level2: Manual procedures, takes a long time
Automation.level3: Mostly manual, delivery times often too long
Automation.level4: Mostly code-driven and automated, delivery times fairly acceptable

Automation.question: To what extent is sharing of knowledge and capabilities in the team(s) facilitated by tooling?
Automation.level1: No active sharing in the team
Automation.level2: A joint knowledge platform, but not actively used
Automation.level3: Joint knowledge platform is being used
Automation.level4: X-functional teams, who actively share roles, responsibilities, activities and knowledge

Automation.question: What level of transparency, by use of tooling, do your team(s) expose with regard to their work in progress (WIP)?
Automation.level1: No visualisation nor registration of WIP
Automation.level2: Registration of WIP in tool, no visual boards
Automation.level3: Some activities are visualised on a shared board
Automation.level4: Visual boards are actively used for visualising WIP, not managed by WIP limits

Automation.question: What is the average quality (result) of your current integrations?
Automation.level2: Integrations usually generate many issues, not done frequently
Automation.level3: Fair, acceptable amount of quality issues
Automation.level4: High, low amount of integration issues due to regular integrations

Automation.question: What is your integration frequency?
Automation.level2: Monthly
Automation.level3: Per sprint
Automation.level4: Daily

Automation.question: How advanced is your log analysis capability?
Automation.level2: Only ad hoc, manual log analysis
Automation.level3: Partly automated analysis, mostly manual
Automation.level4: Automated analysis, manual mitigations

Automation.question: How are possible events, triggered by monitoring, handled within your team(s)?
Automation.level1: We do not have any monitoring in place. All events come from our users.
Automation.level2: We have some basic monitoring in place, only for our production environments, but handling takes place manually, mostly by the operations team
Automation.level3: Monitoring is in place for our production environments, events that are triggered are registered in our service management system, and are dispatched automatically to the operations or support team
Automation.level4: Monitoring is in place for prod environments, some monitoring on non-prod environments, events are handled in a semi-automated way, mostly picked up first by operations & support, but dev teams are nearby for additional support

Automation.question: What is the scope and quality of your CMDB (Configuration Management Database)?
Automation.level2: There is a CMDB, but it only contains some infrastructural components. The quality of the data is not very reliable and rather outdated. It is mostly maintained by a configuration manager
Automation.level3: The CMDB contains basic relationships between application and infrastructure layers and components. Some designated roles are appointed to maintain the database, the quality and reliability of the data is reasonable
Automation.level4: The CMDB is maintained by many team members, and its data has a fair reliability. Some discovery is done for applications, software and infrastructure components, but most of the data collection and impact analyses involve manual activities

Automation.question: To what extent is your change management process automated?
Automation.level1: We don't have a change management process, neither do we have any pipelines set up for changes, everything happens on ad hoc basis
Automation.level2: We have a robust change management process in place, which is managed by a change manager. Execution of the process takes place manually, has CAB meetings with frequency of once a week or lower, and takes too much time due to approvals and waiting time
Automation.level3: We have a change management process in place, which deals with all medium and major changes, including a CAB. Throughput times are fairly acceptable and CABs can be planned on flexible times
Automation.level4: We have a change management process in place, which only needs to deal with x-team dependencies (releasing, impact analysis) and complex decision making for unprecedented request types. The rest is automated

Collaboration.question: How is the work distributed within the team
Collaboration.level1: Push is used, no pull present in the teams. Push is one-way information, so mostly fire-and-forget
Collaboration.level2: Push is used to distribute and allocate the work, no pull in place. Team members need to confirm they pick up the items assigned to them.
Collaboration.level3: Mix of push and pull. Some tasks and stories are assigned by push, others are pulled by the team members. No buffers or Ready columns visible to pull work from.
Collaboration.level4: Most work is pulled by the team members. Ready work is made visible, so that team members can pull their work items

Collaboration.question: What is the level of standardisation within the organisation?
Collaboration.level1: No standardisation nor reuse between roles and teams
Collaboration.level2: Standards are defined and caught in processes and procedures. It is perceived as bureaucratic for the teams
Collaboration.level3: Several standards have been defined, which the teams need to comply with. There is some room for deviation from the standards, but it is not stimulated or enabled
Collaboration.level4: Standardisation is minimal, to encourage maximum team autonomy. Sharing is used to enable x-team reuse of technology and practices

Collaboration.question: To what extent is your team (or organization if you are involved with multiple teams) focused on reducing the waste?
Collaboration.level1: There is no focus on reducing waste
Collaboration.level2: Only specialists are focusing on reducing waste
Collaboration.level3: Team members know how to recognize and eliminate waste, but it is not structurally performed
Collaboration.level4: On a periodic (but not very frequent, < once per year) basis, team members actively search for waste reduction opportunities and are mandated to take these away

Collaboration.question: To what extent are the value streams identified within your team or delivery chain?
Collaboration.level1: There are no value streams known
Collaboration.level2: One or more value streams are known and described in documents, but have no relation to the actual work & decision making (priorities)
Collaboration.level3: The value streams are visible and known to everyone involved, but are not actively being used in decision making (priorities)
Collaboration.level4: The value streams are visible and evolve continuously, the teams are aware of their contribution to these value streams. Decision making on value stream level is not directly aligned with team level decisions

Collaboration.question: How does your team or your delivery chain deal with bottlenecks (constraints)?
Collaboration.level2: Bottlenecks are identified, but resolving them takes too much time, causing too much negative impact
Collaboration.level3: Because we visualize most of our work, bottlenecks are identified in some cases and eliminated, mostly driven by the Scrum Master. This process is not shared between dev and ops
Collaboration.level4: Because we visualize all of our work, bottlenecks become visible instantly and are identified and eliminated effectively by the Scrum Master. Focus is mostly on dev or ops, not a joint effort

Collaboration.question: Who are responsible for improvements within the organization?
Collaboration.level1: No one is responsible for improvements
Collaboration.level2: Line or process managers are responsible for improvements
Collaboration.level3: Team members are responsible for improvements, managers are responsible for decisions
Collaboration.level4: Team members are responsible for improvements and make decisions within their scope, managers are coaching/facilitating

Collaboration.question: To what extent is the organization using visual management?
Collaboration.level2: Visual management only by a few teams, for their own progress tracking
Collaboration.level3: Visual management is used by multiple teams, but mostly in development teams, not for operations and support. It is only used for progress tracking
Collaboration.level4: Visual management is used by all teams, mostly on operational level, but by both development and support/operations teams. Occasionally visual management is also used by tactical/strategic levels (management/board), mostly for x-team impediments

Collaboration.question: To what extent does your team use direct feedback loops?
Collaboration.level1: No daily stand-ups, no knowledge is collected of release results, no demos are provided.
Collaboration.level2: Feedback loops do not cross functional roles. Developers do not deliver feedback to operations or vice versa. Some procedures are in place to force feedback, but they are not part of daily practice or behaviour
Collaboration.level3: Most teams are using daily stand-ups. In some teams, operators join the development team stand-ups, and occasionally join their demos. Business owners and key users are infrequently informed by the PO.
Collaboration.level4: Daily stand-ups are used on all levels, including management and other stakeholders. The business is not very much aligned yet, they have other feedback mechanisms, because they do not have much time available for IT stuff

Collaboration.question: What is the mandate, role & scope of the Product Owner?
Collaboration.level2: One or more Product Owners have been assigned, but they are not very active, have very little time available for the team
Collaboration.level3: There are multiple Product Owners, no clear ownership and allocation of responsibilities
Collaboration.level4: There is one single Product Owner for the team and their backlog. The PO is mandated, has enough time available for the team, is knowledgeable, but is not involved or does not care about non-functional issues and changes

Collaboration.question: To what extent does your product or service delivery methodology support continuous delivery?
Collaboration.level1: No clear standards and delivery processes used. Going live is always a serious struggle, ad hoc driven, with many incidents occurring after go-live and dissatisfying handover processes and results.
Collaboration.level2: Release management is rigid, leading to long test and wait times (approvals). Mostly waterfall processes are used. Large batches are used (releases), few releases per year
Collaboration.level3: Agile methodologies are being used, but these do not involve the operations and support of the value chain. Going live is done after the actual (development) sprint
Collaboration.level4: Sprints are being used as release containers, so within each sprint the product increments will be brought live. Usually at the end of the sprint, after the demo

Collaboration.question: To what extent are your deployments done manually?
Collaboration.level2: Completely manual, with structured procedures
Collaboration.level3: Mostly manual, some scripts
Collaboration.level4: Mostly automated, some manual interventions

Collaboration.question: How do you track and measure the quality of your deployments?
Collaboration.level2: Fully manual measurement, ad hoc
Collaboration.level3: Manual, but structural measurement
Collaboration.level4: Some automated tests

Collaboration.question: How long does it take for one line of code from the moment it is written until it is put into production?
Collaboration.level2: 5-10 days
Collaboration.level3: 2-5 days
Collaboration.level4: Hours

Collaboration.question: How do you provision new build and test environments?
Collaboration.level2: Manual procedures, takes a long time
Collaboration.level3: Mostly manual, delivery times often too long
Collaboration.level4: Mostly code-driven and automated, delivery times fairly acceptable

Collaboration.question: How do you provision new production environments?
Collaboration.level2: Manual procedures, takes a long time
Collaboration.level3: Mostly manual, delivery times often too long
Collaboration.level4: Mostly code-driven and automated, delivery times fairly acceptable

Collaboration.question: To what extent is sharing of knowledge and capabilities in the team(s) facilitated by tooling?
Collaboration.level1: No active sharing in the team
Collaboration.level2: A joint knowledge platform, but not actively used
Collaboration.level3: Joint knowledge platform is being used
Collaboration.level4: X-functional teams, who actively share roles, responsibilities, activities and knowledge

Collaboration.question: What level of transparency, by use of tooling, do your team(s) expose with regard to their work in progress (WIP)?
Collaboration.level1: No visualisation nor registration of WIP
Collaboration.level2: Registration of WIP in tool, no visual boards
Collaboration.level3: Some activities are visualised on a shared board
Collaboration.level4: Visual boards are actively used for visualising WIP, not managed by WIP limits

Collaboration.question: What is the average quality (result) of your current integrations?
Collaboration.level2: Integrations usually generate many issues, not done frequently
Collaboration.level3: Fair, acceptable amount of quality issues
Collaboration.level4: High, low amount of integration issues due to regular integrations

Collaboration.question: What is your integration frequency?
Collaboration.level2: Monthly
Collaboration.level3: Per sprint
Collaboration.level4: Daily

Collaboration.question: How advanced is your log analysis capability?
Collaboration.level2: Only ad hoc, manual log analysis
Collaboration.level3: Partly automated analysis, mostly manual
Collaboration.level4: Automated analysis, manual mitigations

Collaboration.question: How are possible events, triggered by monitoring, handled within your team(s)?
Collaboration.level1: We do not have any monitoring in place. All events come from our users.
Collaboration.level2: We have some basic monitoring in place, only for our production environments, but handling takes place manually, mostly by the operations team
Collaboration.level3: Monitoring is in place for our production environments, events that are triggered are registered in our service management system, and are dispatched automatically to the operations or support team
Collaboration.level4: Monitoring is in place for prod environments, some monitoring on non-prod environments, events are handled in a semi-automated way, mostly picked up first by operations & support, but dev teams are nearby for additional support

Collaboration.question: What is the scope and quality of your CMDB (Configuration Management Database)?
Collaboration.level2: There is a CMDB, but it only contains some infrastructural components. The quality of the data is not very reliable and rather outdated. It is mostly maintained by a configuration manager
Collaboration.level3: The CMDB contains basic relationships between application and infrastructure layers and components. Some designated roles are appointed to maintain the database, the quality and reliability of the data is reasonable
Collaboration.level4: The CMDB is maintained by many team members, and its data has a fair reliability. Some discovery is done for applications, software and infrastructure components, but most of the data collection and impact analyses involve manual activities

Collaboration.question: To what extent is your change management process automated?
Collaboration.level1: We don't have a change management process, neither do we have any pipelines set up for changes, everything happens on ad hoc basis
Collaboration.level2: We have a robust change management process in place, which is managed by a change manager. Execution of the process takes place manually, has CAB meetings with frequency of once a week or lower, and takes too much time due to approvals and waiting time
Collaboration.level3: We have a change management process in place, which deals with all medium and major changes, including a CAB. Throughput times are fairly acceptable and CABs can be planned on flexible times
Collaboration.level4: We have a change management process in place, which only needs to deal with x-team dependencies (releasing, impact analysis) and complex decision making for unprecedented request types. The rest is automated

Metrics.question: To what level are the primary business goals shared across all parties and roles in the delivery chain?
Metrics.level2: Primary business goals are known, but not shared within the organisation
Metrics.level3: Primary business goals are known, and shared across the organisation and translated to sub goals for suppliers/partners
Metrics.level4: Primary business goals are known and shared across the organisation including external parties

Metrics.question: To what extent has business value been integrated throughout the entire delivery chain as a primary driver?
Metrics.level2: Business value has been defined by IT
Metrics.level3: Business value has been defined by the customer/business, but not measured
Metrics.level4: Business value has been defined by the customer/business and is measured, but not shared across all teams and organisations in the chain

Metrics.question: Which are the most dominant metric areas used in your team (or, if you're involved with multiple teams, in your domain/organization)?
Metrics.level1: We have no idea of the most important metrics

Sharing.question: How does your team (or your organisation, if you deal with multiple teams) deal with dependencies?
Sharing.level2: Dependencies are known, but not shared between teams
Sharing.level3: Dependencies are known, shared between teams, but not actively managed
Sharing.level4: Dependencies between teams are known, defined, and are continuously managed by the respected teams and the coordinating layer

Sharing.question: How does your organisation deal with shared infrastructure and its relation to the teams' activities?
Sharing.level1: There is no clear responsibility who does what regarding infrastructure
Sharing.level2: All infrastructure is managed centrally, and most of it is on-premises, the teams have no say in this nor knowledge about the details
Sharing.level3: There is an internal infrastructure team, responsible for the generic infrastructure, which is partly cloud-based. They enable and support the teams in their infrastructure demand.
Sharing.level4: There is an internal infrastructure team, responsible for the generic infrastructure, which is partly cloud-based. They facilitate, support and train the teams to optimize them for self-service.

Sharing.question: What is your average release cadence for your core, legacy and/or backend systems?
Sharing.level1: We have no idea what our release cadence is

Sharing.question: What is your average release cadence for your front-end/mobile systems?
Sharing.level1: We have no idea what our release cadence is
Sharing.level4: At least once per week or per iteration

Sharing.question: To which extent are communities integrated in normal ways of working?
Sharing.level1: We have no communities within the organization which actively share knowledge
Sharing.level2: We have one or more communities which are not very active currently
Sharing.level3: We have a number of active communities within the organization, however the teams and communities do not explicitly share dependencies and knowledge with other communities
Sharing.level4: Our organization visibly consists of multiple communities and networks of teams and individuals, where everyone actively contributes to their team and communities. All communities proactively interact with other communities regarding dependent themes. Communities have most of their activities/events outside business hours

Sharing.question: To which extent is knowledge sharing rewarded in your organisation?
Sharing.level1: Knowledge sharing is not considered as a relevant topic by management
Sharing.level2: Knowledge sharing is regarded as a relevant topic within the organization, but it is only being done in a fragmented and ad hoc manner
Sharing.level3: Knowledge sharing is desired, but not explicitly defined as desired behaviour, and not measured or actively rewarded
Sharing.level4: Knowledge sharing is defined a desired behaviour, but is not measured or actively rewarded

Sharing.question: How are impediments dealt with in your organisation?
Sharing.level1: Impediments are not explicitly defined or visualised
Sharing.level2: Impediments are transferred to a risk manager
Sharing.level3: Impediments are picked up by the team, and impediments superseding the influence of the team are picked up by the above management layer
Sharing.level4: All impediments are visually available to every possible stakeholder at any possible time

Sharing.question: How are emergent (good) practices shared within and/or across the teams?
Sharing.level1: Good practices are not shared between teams
Sharing.level2: Good practices are standardized and rolled out to all teams, by means of procedures, templates and instructions
Sharing.level3: Good practices are collected by a central support function, then distributed to the teams for possible reuse
Sharing.level4: Good practices are actively shared by the teams, by means of community events, guilds, demos, meet-ups and shared via a central repository of templates

Sharing.question: How is the classification & administration of security levels and attributes organised in your team (or organisation, if your scope spans multiple teams)?
Sharing.level1: Security is not a relevant topic in our team
Sharing.level2: There is a Security Officer in our organisation, but he/she is not involved with the team. Some guidelines/policies have been set
Sharing.level3: There is some contact between the Security officer and the team, where mostly the Security officer has classified the product(s) and is maintaining the required information on this
Sharing.level4: A Security Officer is closely involved with team, and advises the teams continuously on the best options. Classification has been done by the Security officer and/or Product Owner, the security administration is largely done by the team

Sharing.question: Where is budgeting & cost-related decision making addressed in your team (or in your organisation, if your scope spans multiple teams)?
Sharing.level1: There is no clear accountability set for budgeting nor decision making in the team and/or organisation
Sharing.level2: (Senior) line management is accountable and responsible for all budgeting & other cost-related decision making
Sharing.level3: The Product Owner has a delegated mandate for budget and cost-related decisions, but in a lot of cases needs to check with line management (program/projects, operations, licenses, out-of-pocket costs, etc.)
Sharing.level4: The Product Owner has a full mandate on all budgets and decision making around the product(s) concerned, but only for the development and maintenance costs. Operational costs (infrastructure, contracts, services) are not part of his/her accountability

Architecture.question: How mature is your Architecture capability?
Architecture.level1: Solutions for projects are unpredictable, poorly controlled and reactive
Architecture.level2: Architecture characterised for projects are often reactive
Architecture.level3: Architecture characterised for projects are proactive
Architecture.level4: Architecture and operational services are measured and controlled

Architecture.question: How does your project team design solutions?
Architecture.level1: Each project in separation with no sharing / re-use of common building blocks
Architecture.level2: Some projects sharing and re-using common building blocks
Architecture.level3: Many projects sharing and re-using common building blocks with some projects developing new building blocks to be used by other projects at a later stage
Architecture.level4: Most projects are sharing and re-using common building blocks with most projects + developing new building blocks to be used by other projects at a later stage

Architecture.question: How does your team (or your organisation, if you deal with multiple teams) include architecture in your products and way of working?
Architecture.level1: There is no architecture known, no principles set or rules defined
Architecture.level2: Architecture mostly comprises a set of rules to be used across all teams, which are defined in architectural documentation. There is no active assurance of these architectural rules in the teams
Architecture.level3: Architectural principles have been set, but are not updated or evolving frequently. Teams mostly apply the principles, but there is no direct feedback mechanism between the architects and the teams
Architecture.level4: An intentional architecture is set, which is fully aimed at enabling principle-based sharing of tools, technology and practices. The emerging architecture is added to this architectural runway manually. There is alignment between the dev and ops architecture, yet there may be some differences

Architecture.question: How does your project use and apply Architecture Tools in order to speed up, increase value for money and improve quality
Architecture.level1: No use of any architecture tools
Architecture.level2: Architecture tools are only being used during planning phase
Architecture.level3: Architecture tools are used during planning and design phase
Architecture.level4: Architecture tools are an essential mechanism to address DevOps related aspects
